title: Can we use “got” with the 3rd form of a verb? - Quora

response.answer_text: ‘Third form' of a verb (Numbers from one to nine are spelled out.) is a term used by British ESL/EFL teachers. American ESL/EFL teachers don't use it. It's not a very useful term because it's completely abstract. Unlike terms like past participle, passive participle, or simple past, the expression 'third form' gives you absolutely no clue as to its meaning. I'm going to try to guess what you mean. The word got has many different meanings. Sometimes it means became. When it means became it is a linking verb and is followed by a subject complement. The subject complement in this case is always an adjective. Here are some examples: He got old.He got tired.He got hungry.He got mad.He got drunk.All these words are adjectives. None of them are verbs. Sometimes, in passive verb phrases, the word got means was or were. She got injured in the accident.She got eaten by a bear.She got killed by a falling piano.In this case, since these are passive constructions, the word got is followed by the passive participle. If you call the passive participle the “third form” of the verb, then the answer is yes.

First, I hadn’t heard of “3rd form of a verb” until i Started reading Quora, and I’ve been speaking English for more than 70 years. The normal term is “past participle”. It’s a better term than “3rd form”, because it says what it means, and because some English verbs have more than 4 forms, while others have fewer. So, you can use “got” with a past participle in English, but you would not use it is very formal contexts, For example: I got dressed.The house got built,He got hit by a car.She got embarrassed.These are all normal English, but I would not use these writing a formal report. There I might say: The author of this report dressed.The house was built,Mr X was hit by a car.Ms Y was embarrassed.

If you mean “3rd tense “ of the verb, then the answer is yes. You can use it as in: I got it, you got it, he got it, we got it, you got (plural) and finally they got it! I hope “it” wasn’t a nasty disease!!

The infinitive to get and it’s forms are a very weak verb. You can almost always find another better verb to use in its CNN place. However, it does have a 3rd. person form. He gets, he got, he has gotten.
Yes we can use got or gotten both as third form . Present—- get Past —- got Past participle (third form of verb) — got or gotten .
